clinical_study.brief_title: Study of Sitagliptin Treatment in Patients With Type 2 Diabetes During Ramadan (0431-263)
clinical_study.official_title: An Open-Label, Randomized Naturalistic Study to Evaluate the Incidence of Hypoglycemia Comparing Sitagliptin With Sulfonylurea Treatment in Patients With Type 2 Diabetes During Ramadan Fasting

brief_summary.textblock: This study will examine whether the incidence of hypoglycemia in patients fasting for Ramadan is lower when treated with sitagliptin as compared to sulfonylurea treatment.

detailed_description.textblock: This study and NCT01340768 (MK-0431-262) have the same design but are conducted under separate protocols, in different countries, according to local guidelines.

primary_outcome.measure: Proportion of Participants With at Least One Symptomatic Hypoglycemic Event
primary_outcome.time_frame: 30 days: first day of Ramadan (August 11) to last day of Ramadan (September 10)
primary_outcome.description: Symptomatic hypoglycemic event was determined based on the participant's self-reported symptoms including faintness, headache, confusion, anxiety, sweating, tremor, palpitation, nausea, pallor, dizziness, hunger, and sudden behavioral change.

secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of Participants With at Least One Symptomatic or Asymptomatic Hypoglycemic Event
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 30 days: first day of Ramadan (August 11) to last day of Ramadan (September 10)
secondary_outcome.description: Hypoglycemic event was based on the participant's self-report and/or finger-stick blood glucose level. Symptomatic hypoglycemic symptoms included faintness, headache, confusion, anxiety, sweating, tremor, palpitation, nausea, pallor, dizziness, hunger, and sudden behavioral change.

arm_group.description: Sitagliptin 100 mg administered orally daily as monotherapy or in combination with metformin over the Ramadan period.
Sulfonylurea administered orally daily as monotherapy or in combination with metformin over the Ramadan period.

intervention.description: Sitagliptin 100 mg tablet administered orally once daily over the Ramadan period.
Sulfonylurea (glibenclamide, glimepiride, or gliclazide) administered orally daily over the Ramadan period as per physician's prescription
Participants could continue pre-study metformin as concomitant therapy during the study.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Muslim men and women with type 2 diabetes
- Participants who intend to fast during the month of Ramadan
- Participants who have been on a stable dose of sulfonylurea for at least three months
Exclusion Criteria:
- Participants with type 1 diabetes mellitus
- Pregnant or breast feeding women
- Participants with hypersensitivity or contraindication to dipeptidyl peptidase (DPP-4) treatment
- Participants on insulin
- Participants on any class of oral diabetic therapy other than sulfonylurea or metformin

The incidence of hypoglycaemia in Muslim patients with type 2 diabetes treated with sitagliptin or a sulphonylurea during Ramadan: a randomised trial. Int J Clin Pract. 2011 Nov;65(11):1132-40. doi: 10.1111/j.1742-1241.2011.02797.x. Epub 2011 Sep 27.
